projects.title: Invoice application
projects.description: A web application that allows users to store complete or incomplete invoices, delete a stored invoice, mark an invoice as paid, and filter invoices by status. The stored data is protected using a custom authentication and authorization flow.

projects.title: Audiophile e-commerce website
projects.description: A website that displays electronic gadgets of an imaginary brand named "Audiophile". A user can view items by category, add/delete products from the cart, edit product quantities in the cart, and checkout.

projects.title: Tic Tac Toe game
projects.description: A game to play solo or with someone. It doesn't use any technology that connects two browsers yet, so both the players will have to share the same browser tab while playing the game if the "multiplayer" option is selected.

onlineCourses.name: CSS for JavaScript developers
onlineCourses.background: I've always had a hard time working with CSS. Building personal projects and working professionally using CSS helped me get better, but I still didn't feel completely confident. It bothered me not to have confidence in working with the technology I get paid for. One important lesson I learned while using CSS is to learn CSS concepts, not specific properties. Docs are always at my disposal, helping me understand the details of a given property. The course offered by Josh really resonated with this idea.

onlineCourses.name: Full stack open
onlineCourses.background: After working on my final year project, where I was responsible for building a machine learning model for the "image manipulation detection" problem, I wanted to create a frontend to let my friends and potential employers explore my project. I realized there was so much I didn't know about in the frontend world of web development. Knowing this, one of my college friends recommended this course.

onlineCourses.name: The Bits and Bytes of Computer Networking
onlineCourses.background: During the COVID-19 pandemic, my college helped students study by providing access to paid Coursera courses. While exploring the courses offered by Coursera, this course caught my attention. I was curious to learn more about how computers communicate. In the following semester, I had to take a course on computer networking. I thought taking this course would help me get a basic idea of computer networks.

onlineCourses.name: Programming Foundations with JavaScript, HTML and CSS
onlineCourses.background: During the COVID-19 pandemic, the computer engineering department of my college had planned a crash course covering the basics of frontend web development. After taking the course, I wanted to learn more about HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

onlineCourses.name: SQL and PostgreSQL
onlineCourses.background: For some reason, I don't enjoy writing SQL queries. Maybe the Database Management System course I had taken didn't do a good job? Maybe writing SQL queries is just not for me? But, as a software developer, it's important to know how to write SQL queries and handle databases at a basic level. I decided to take this course in order to gain some basic knowledge of PostgreSQL and build a backend for one of my personal projects.

onlineCourses.name: Python Classes and Inheritance
onlineCourses.background: I realized that I had a basic understanding of C, C++, Java, and Python during the third year of my four-year degree in computer engineering and that it was time for me to choose a programming language and master it. I picked Python and started taking courses to master it.

onlineCourses.name: Machine Learning
onlineCourses.background: At the end of 2020, I had a good understanding of Python programming but didn't know what to do next or which software engineering field might interest me. In a short conversation with a senior student, he mentioned that I might enjoy learning about machine learning. I decided to take this course a few days after that conversation to learn more about machine learning.

onlineCourses.name: Deep Learning
onlineCourses.background: The next natural step most students take after completing the Coursera machine learning course, which is recommended, is to study the topics of this specialization course, and I did exactly that.

onlineCourses.name: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)
onlineCourses.background: After having a basic understanding of most of the commonly used deep learning concepts, there was an entire area of deep learning that I had very little idea of: teaching machines to generate something. Wait, no. This can't be done. That's how I reacted the first time. I got motivated to explore more about the subject and ended up taking this course.

languages.name: HTML, CSS & JavaScript
languages.background: I learned to work with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript while I was studying for my computer engineering degree, and I have continued to use them since then. For nearly a year, JavaScript was my primary language for personal projects.

languages.name: TypeScript
languages.background: I started using TypeScript professionally in 2023. It has become my go-to language and will continue to be the default for all of my personal frontend projects.

languages.name: Python
languages.background: In mid-2020, I started learning Python through Coursera courses. Since then, I have built a few machine learning models while learning about machine learning. I've also been using Python for most of the programming problems on Leetcode. I don't have any professional experience using this language.

libraries & frameworks.name: React
libraries & frameworks.background: I have been using React for more than a year now. It is the first and only UI framework I have used to build user interfaces for personal and professional projects.

libraries & frameworks.name: Next.js
libraries & frameworks.background: From August 2023, I started exploring Next.js and began to develop some projects that have made use of it. This website is built using Next.js!

libraries & frameworks.name: TailwindCSS
libraries & frameworks.background: I have been using TailwindCSS for more than a year. It is and will be the default styling choice for all of my personal front-end projects. I have a decent mental model of the commonly used CSS concepts. So using a different styling option for professional use is no big deal.

libraries & frameworks.name: Express
libraries & frameworks.background: I use Express whenever I need a web server. I learned about Express while taking a course about full-stack web development in mid-2022.

libraries & frameworks.name: Redux
libraries & frameworks.background: I learned why and how to use Redux in mid-2022. Apart from that, I have worked with Redux professionally while adding a feature to CometChat's dashboard.

tools & platforms.name: Git
tools & platforms.background: Git was the primary version control system used by the company I was working for. Most of the Git related tasks I completed were to create, merge, or compare branches and revert changes.

tools & platforms.name: Github
tools & platforms.background: I use Github most of the time to create remote repositories for my local git repositories. In addition, I'm aware of the regularly used Github rules followed by developers for effective collaboration.

databases.name: PostgreSQL
databases.background: I used a SQL-based database while I was studying for my computer engineering degree. I don't use PostgreSQL often, as most of the time I work on the frontend of an application, but whenever I need a general database for a personal project, I plan to use PostgreSQL.
